1em!important;width:auto!important}div#onetrust-consent-sdk button:hover{background-color:#fff!important;border-color:#eb6500!important;color:#2e2e2e!important}div#onetrust-consent-sdk publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. of Colloid and Interface Science</span></span></a></h2><div class="text-xs"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/journal/journal-of-colloid-and-interface-science/vol/629/part/PB" title="Go to table of contents for this volume/issue"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Volume 629, Part B</span></span></a>, January 2023, Pages 1061-1067</div></div><div class="publication-cover u-display-block-from-sm"><a class="anchor u-display-flex anchor-primary" href="/journal/journal-of-colloid-and-interface-science/vol/629/part/PB"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><img class="publication-cover-image" src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979722X00209-cov150h.gif" alt="Journal of Colloid and Interface Science"></span></span></a></div></div><h1 id="screen-reader-main-title" class="Head u-font-serif u-h2 u-margin-s-ver"><span class="title-text">Engineering crystal-facet modulation to obtain stable Mn-based <em>P</em>2-layered oxide cathodes for sodium-ion batteries</span></h1><div class="Banner" id="banner"><div class="wrapper truncated"><div aria-live="polite"></div><div class="AuthorGroups"><div class="author-group" id="author-group"><span class="sr-only">Author links open overlay panel</span><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-underline" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2022.09.065" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2022.09.065</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author" id="ab010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010">The undesirable phase transformation of Mn-based <em>P</em><span>2-layered <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxide</a> cathodes is a tremendous challenge in commercializing Mn-based oxide cathodes for sodium-ion batteries. In this work, Na</span><sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode with stable <em>P</em>2-type structure was successfully synthesized by modulating its coordination numbers to suppress the preferred orientation growth of (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;1) crystal plane, which was realized to maintain a stable <em>P</em>2-type structure in the whole state of charging and discharging. Specifically, designing Mn<sup>2+</sup> six coordination sites to lower the high surface energy of (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;1) crystal plane is an effective way to reduce nucleation rates, which leads to the production of few grain boundaries and the suppression of layer-to-layer stacking in the crystal growth stage. Due to their fewer grain boundaries and skeleton structure with layer-to-layer stacking, the interlaminar stress and intragranular fatigue cracks can be alleviated in the long-life cycling performance of Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode. Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathodes derived from the precursor of Mn<sup>2+</sup> six coordination sites (C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>) have more exposed {0&nbsp;1&nbsp;0} crystal face and enlarged sodium-ion diffusion channels and structure integrity compared to Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode prepared by the precursor of Mn<sup>2+</sup> four coordination sites (O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>). Therefore, C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode delivers an initial capacity of 106.8 mAh/g and has excellent capacity retention of 94.8&nbsp;% after 150 cycles at 80 mAh/g. The rational design strategy endows Mn-based <em>P</em><span>2-layered oxide cathodes with stable sodium-ion diffusion channels and <a href="/topics/materials-science/lamellar-structure" title="Learn more about lamellar structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lamellar structure</a>.</span></div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="ab005" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="as005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0005"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-ga1.jpg" height="200" alt=""><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (161KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (161KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979722016800"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979722018707"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kg005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keyword</h2><div id="k0005" class="keyword"><span>Crystal-facet modulation stable <em>P</em>2-type structure sodium-ion batteries</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st025" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">The ever-growing demand for portable electronics and electric vehicles has strongly led to the development of low-cost energy storage techniques, which compensate for the depletion of lithium resources and reduce the cost of electric vehicles <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0010" name="bb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0015" name="bb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>. The sodium-ion battery (SIB) technology has shown to be a promising alternative to lithium-ion batteries, with the merit of wide geographical distribution, rich natural abundance and inexpensive cost in comparison to Li. <em>P</em><span><span>2-layered <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxide</a> cathodes have attracted a great deal of attention due to their low-cost, desirable sodium-ion diffusion channels and relatively high </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0020" name="bb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>. In contrast to other layered oxide cathodes, such as Na<sub>0.66</sub>Li<sub>0.22</sub>Ru<sub>0.78</sub>O<sub>2</sub><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0030" name="bb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, Na<sub>0.78</sub>Co<sub>1/2</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>Ni<sub>1/6</sub>O<sub>2</sub><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, there is high competition for Mn-based <em>P</em>2-layered oxide cathodes due to their low cost, low toxicity, environmental friendliness, and abundance in nature. However, <em>P</em>2-type Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode is hampered by the following issues: (1) irreversible phase transitions stemming from <em>P</em>2-OP4 and <em>P</em>2- <em>P</em>2 structure transition during cycling,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a> (2) loss of active materials on the electrode resulting from cracked particles reacting with electrolyte, (3) poor air-stability.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">Extensive efforts have been devoted to enhancing the structural stability of Mn-based <em>P</em><span>2-layered oxide cathodes, which makes them to have long-life cycling performance. The structure modulation technology has been classified into morphology design, doping-integrated <a href="/topics/materials-science/coating-technology" title="Learn more about coating technology from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coating technology</a> and engineering of biphasic hybridization, such as uniform </span><em>P</em>2-Na<sub>0.7</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/microsphere" title="Learn more about microspheres from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">microspheres</a> cathode </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@<em>P</em><sub>2</sub>-Na<sub>2/3</sub>Ni<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>2/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0050" name="bb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a> and (Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, ZrO<sub>2</sub>, and TiO<sub>2</sub>)@ <em>P</em>2-Na<sub>0.66</sub>Mn<sub>0.54</sub>Co<sub>0.13</sub>Ni<sub>0.13</sub>O<sub>2</sub> cathodes<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0055" name="bb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <em>P</em>2/O3 biphasic Na<sub>0.67</sub>Mn<sub>0.55</sub>Ni<sub>0.25</sub>Ti<sub>0.2â€“x</sub>Li<sub>x</sub>O<sub>2</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a> and <em>P</em>2(76&nbsp;%)/<em>P</em>3(23&nbsp;%)-Na<sub>0.66</sub>Mn<sub>0.5</sub>Co<sub>0.5</sub>O<sub>2</sub><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a> cathodes. A novel Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@Na<sub>0.67</sub>Zn<sub>0.1</sub>Mn<sub>0.9</sub>O<sub>2</sub> oxide cathode was successfully synthesized to suppress <em>P</em>2- <em>P</em>2 structure transition by Yangâ€™s group <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0070" name="bb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>. The coating layer of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> prevented organic electrolytes from decomposing, which made the cathode to have a high capacity retention of up to 83&nbsp;%. Philipp Adelhelm et al reported a facile strategy for preparing a Coâ€“ and Ni-Free <em>P</em>2/O3 biphasic Na<sub>0.8</sub>Li<sub>0.2</sub>Fe<sub>0.2</sub>Mn<sub>0.6</sub>O<sub>2</sub> cathode, which realized the initial reversible capacity of 174 mAh/g, and capacity retention of 82&nbsp;% after 100 cycles <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0075" name="bb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a><span>. However, the design of morphology may cause the particles of the materials to crack, which is due to the constrained release of interlaminar stresses on specific morphology, and it is required to precisely control experimental parameters. The doping-integrated coating technique is known to increase the diffusion resistance of sodium-ion in the solid materials and it is difficult to control the thickness of coating layer and obtain uniform coating layer on the whole cathodes. Furthermore, with the doping technique, it is not easy to determine the position of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/doping-additives" title="Learn more about dopant from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dopant</a> elements, and it even requires advanced precision instruments for measuring the site occupancy and location of atoms. Engineering of biphasic hybridization is an important factor in increasing the degree of cation mixing and boosting of O redox activity inevitably, leading to irreversible structural changes. Mn-based </span><em>P</em>2-layered oxide cathodes have poor structural stability and cycling performance.<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a> Hence, we report that controlling coordination numbers to suppress the preferred orientation growth of precursors with {0&nbsp;0&nbsp;1} active facet plays a critical role in determining electrochemically active planes for Na<sup>+</sup> migration. Also, it reduces the number of layers stacked along the [0&nbsp;0&nbsp;1] crystallographic direction, which provides stable sodium-ion diffusion channels and alleviates interlaminar stresses. It is well-known that inhibiting the growth of lattice planes with high surface energy can reduce the rate of nucleation, leading to the realization of few grain boundaries in the whole electrode. So, the bulk Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> with multiple grain boundaries can suffer from tremendous stress in long-life cycling. Meanwhile, inhibiting {0&nbsp;0&nbsp;1} active facet favors the faster growth of {0&nbsp;1&nbsp;<span>0} active facet, enabling the electrode with large sodium-ion diffusion channels. By mitigating interlaminar stresses, the <a href="/topics/materials-science/lamellar-structure" title="Learn more about lamellar structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lamellar structure</a> of C-Na</span><sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> appears to only crack, whereas the lamellar structure of O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> seems to be completely separated, compared to the pristine structure in the high-rate or long-life cycling. Furthermore, the exposed active surfaces of O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> lead to the loss of active materials and capacity decay. Therefore, C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode can have outstanding capacity retention of 94.8&nbsp;% (109.8 mAh/g) after 150 cycles at 0.5C (80 mAh/g).</div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0020">As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>a and1b, the unit of MnC<sub>6</sub>H<sub>4</sub>O<sub>7</sub> has six carboxyl coordination sites while the unit of MnC<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> possesses four carboxyl coordination sites <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>. These can lead to the production of two exposed crystal faces with high surface energy for MnC<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> in the high-temperature pyrolysis. As the exposed crystal faces have high surface energy, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>c shows that the precursor of O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> has distinctive (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;1) preferred orientation compared to the other samples, and the intensity of the diffraction peaks is twice that of the other samples (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>f). The crystalline structures and phase purity of A-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>, O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span> were evaluated by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/rietveld-refinement" title="Learn more about Rietveld refinement from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Rietveld refinement</a> analysis of C-Na</span><sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD pattern from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD pattern</a> is presented in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figure S1</span></span></a>. It can be seen from <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figure S1</span></span></a> that all the characteristic peaks can be well indexed to a typical <em>P</em>2 phase with the <em>P</em>63/<em>mmc</em> space group (Na<sub>0.7</sub>MnO<sub>2.05</sub>-type, JCPDS 27â€“0751), and C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> have distinctly preferred orientation compared to A-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span><span>. This shows that coordination design can lead to the realization of the preferred orientation and high degree of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a>. Meanwhile, the </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/grain-size" title="Learn more about grain size from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">grain size</a> of C-Na</span><sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> is 949&nbsp;nm, which is larger than that of O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> (706&nbsp;nm). Regarding O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>, the smaller the grain size, the more the grain boundaries are exposed, which can make it very difficult to alleviate interlaminar stresses. The particles of O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> gave rise to larger interlaminar cracks in the long-life cycling. Finally, the newly exposed active facets underwent a side reaction to produce new cathode-electrolyte interphase, which resulted in capacity decay. In contrast to O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>, C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span> has the larger <a href="/topics/materials-science/lattice-constant" title="Learn more about lattice parameter from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameter</a> c (11.24&nbsp;Ã…) in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figure S2</span></span></a> than O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> (11.12&nbsp;Ã…), so C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span> electrode has greater <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/lattice-parameter" title="Learn more about lattice parameter from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameter</a> c. This shows it has a more exposed {0</span>&nbsp;1&nbsp;0} active facet, and large sodium-ion diffusion channels.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-gr1.jpg" height="471" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (399KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (399KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0015"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. Building unit of (a) MnC<sub>6</sub>H<sub>4</sub>O<sub>7</sub> and (b) MnC<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>, showing the atom labelling scheme. (c) Schematic illustration of the two-step synthesis of O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>.</p></span></span></figure><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-gr2.jpg" height="436" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. Low and high-magnification SEM images of (b, f) C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>, (a, e) O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and (c, g) A- Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span>. <a href="/topics/materials-science/high-resolution-transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about HRTEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM</a> images with an inset corresponding TEM of (d) O-Na</span><sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and (h) C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span>. (i) SEM and the corresponding <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDS</a> mapping images of C-Na</span><sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>.</p></span></span></figure><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-gr3.jpg" height="646" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. (a) Cycling performance of C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>cathodes. (b, e) Galvanostatic chargeâ€“discharge profiles for selected cycles (1st to 150th cycle) of O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>cathodes. (c, f) Galvanostatic chargeâ€“discharge profiles of O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>cathodes at different current densities. (g) Long-term cycling performance of C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>cathodes at 2C.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">The morphology of the as-prepared cathode particles was characterized by scanning electron microscopy. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a-c shows that all the as-prepared cathode particles consist of micrometer sized particles with approximately 1â€“2&nbsp;Î¼m in diameter and C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> particles have smoother surfaces and less agglomeration than the other particles. As depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a-c, O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> particles have very distinctive streaks on the transverse sides; whereas there are no streaks in the C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span> particles. From the result of <a href="/topics/materials-science/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD pattern from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD pattern</a> in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>a and 3d, it can be inferred that the primary particles were accumulated into lines along (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;1) crystal facet; the lines were combined with each other to form faces, and finally, the faces grew along the [0&nbsp;0&nbsp;1] crystallographic direction to produce skeleton structure with distinctive streaks. In comparison to O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> particles, the interlaminar structure of A-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span> has notable cracks, macropores and graininess, indicating poor <a href="/topics/materials-science/lamellar-structure" title="Learn more about lamellar structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lamellar structure</a>. In addition, the elemental mappings demonstrated the uniform distribution of Na, Mn and O in C-Na</span><sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>(<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>i). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>d and 2&nbsp;h present the interplanar spacings of 5.49 and 5.51&nbsp;Ã…, ascribed to (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;2) planes of O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>, respectively. The results are in agreement with the analysis of XRD.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030"><span>To clearly investigate the correlations between the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical property from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical property</a> and coordination design of C-Na</span><sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span> cathodes, their <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> was analyzed. As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a, C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode delivers an initial discharge capacity of 106.8 mAh/g, and still retains 100.5 mAh/g after 150 cycles, realizing superior capacity retention of 94.8&nbsp;%. However, the capacity retention of O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode is merely 66.1&nbsp;%, and the reversible capacity of C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode exceeds 80.2 mAh/g compared to that of O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e displays that the charge/discharge profiles of C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode have no capacity decay and fail to undergo a severe voltage fade during cycling; whereas O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode undergoes a severe voltage fade and capacity decay in the 50th, 100th and 150th cycles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>b), indicating it has stable sodium-ion diffusion channels and structural integrity.<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a> As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c and 3f, when the current density increases to 5C, O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode suffers from a severe specific capacity decay (8 mAh/g), while C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode still retains its capacity of 48 mAh/g, revealing it has poor sodium-ion diffusion channels and unstable lamellar structure. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d shows that the current density increases by 2-, 5-, 10-, 20-, and 50-folds, C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode has the capacity retention of 95&nbsp;%, 87&nbsp;%, 74&nbsp;% and 48&nbsp;% of discharge capacity (100 mAh/g), respectively. C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> electrode still delivers the initial specific capacity of 80 mAh/g at the high current densities of 320 mAh/g, realizing high capacity retention of 75&nbsp;% after 300 cycles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>g).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0035">In order to probe the sodium-ion diffusion kinetics of C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span> cathodes, the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) and <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about cyclic voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cyclic voltammetry</a> were applied to reveal the kinetic characteristics of Mn-based </span><em>P</em><span>2-layered <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxide</a> cathodes.</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a> It can be seen from <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>a and 4b that the sodium-ion <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> (D</span><sub>Na+</sub>) of C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode is 2.87&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’8</sup> cm<sup>2</sup> s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, which exceeds that of O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode (2.46&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’8</sup> cm<sup>2</sup> s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>). The corresponding CV curves are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figure S4</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figure S5</span></span></a>.<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a> The results once again prove the existence of large sodium-ion diffusion channels for C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode, which are in accordance with the analysis of electrochemical performance. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c and 4d, the corresponding average D<sub>Na+</sub> of C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode is around 4.74&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’9</sup> cm<sup>2</sup> s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> in the rectangular area (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d); while the average D<sub>Na+</sub> of O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode is around 2.65&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’9</sup> cm<sup>2</sup> s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. When the potential decreases from 4.2 to 3.8&nbsp;V corresponding rectangular area (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d), the D<sub>Na+</sub> of C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode still goes back to around 10<sup>âˆ’8</sup> cm<sup>2</sup> s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, which is&nbsp;âˆ¼&nbsp;10 times higher than that of O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode. Compared with O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathodes, the improving D<sub>Na+</sub> suggests C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode has superior structural integrity and stable lamellar structure. O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathodes undergo severe D<sub>Na+</sub> decay at the end of the discharge. It corresponds to circular marquee area, which can be ascribed to the destruction of the lamellar structure stemming from Jahn-Teller transitions <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-gr4.jpg" height="409" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (486KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (486KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (a, b) Plot for peak current versus square root of the scan rate of C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathodes. (c, d) GITT curves and corresponding Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/diffusivity" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficients from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficients</a> of C-Na</span><sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathodes in the charge and discharge processes.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0040">SEM and XRD were used to investigate the characteristics of the morphological, microstructural and crystal structure evolution of C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>cathodes after cycling. It was done to unravel the effect of coordination design. It can be observed from <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a and 5d that there are obvious cracks in O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span> electrodes, which stemmed from the accumulated interlaminar stress caused by the resistance of crystal boundaries of the lamellar structure to <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crack-propagation" title="Learn more about crack propagation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crack propagation</a>. Compared with O-Na</span><sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> electrodes, C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span> electrodes still maintain their electrode integrity, and they have residual <a href="/topics/materials-science/porous-glass" title="Learn more about porous glass from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porous glass</a> fibers as membrane on their surface (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a). As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b and 5e, there are multiple fracturings in O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> particle, while C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> particle has only one mini open crack. The illustration of microstructural structure evolution was used to describe the destruction of lamellar structure integrity, which stemmed from the stripes that evolved from multiple grain boundaries in O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> particle (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c). However, C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> still maintains its particle integrity; it has mini crack after 150 cycles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>f). It can be observed from <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>g that the (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;2) diffraction peak at 2<em>Î¸</em><span>&nbsp;=&nbsp;15.95Â°shifts to a lower angle after charging from 2.15 to 2.6&nbsp;V at 0.2C. It was caused by enhancing the repulsive <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrostatics" title="Learn more about electrostatic from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrostatic</a> interaction between adjacent MO</span><sub>2</sub><span> sheets and the irreversible <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reactions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reactions</a>. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a> When it charged further from 3.8 up to 4.2&nbsp;V, the whole diffraction peaks matched well with <em>P</em>2-type structure and the new diffraction peaks at 12.16Â°corresponded to hydrated peak rather than OP4, O2, or Z phase<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>. This indicates C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> has outstanding structural reversibility. The wide diffraction peaks at 22.55Â°corresponded to adhesive tape, caused by sticking the electrode material on the adhesive tape in the process of measurement. C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>cathode discharged from 4.2 to 3.4&nbsp;V until it got to 2.8&nbsp;V, in which the XRD patterns of C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>cathode still fit well with <em>P</em>2-type structure. The results of ex-situ XRD patterns suggest that the reaction fails to undergo consecutive phase transitions (P P P) in the overall state of charging and discharging. This demonstrates that inhibiting the preferred orientation growth of {0&nbsp;0&nbsp;1} planes, with coordination design of Mn<sup>2+</sup> and six carbonyls can help C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>cathode to have stable <em>P</em>2-type structure, sodium-ion diffusion channels and structural integrity.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-gr5.jpg" height="560" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S002197972201640X-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. Low and high-magnification SEM images of (d, e) C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and (a, b) O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathodes in the discharged state of 2.15&nbsp;V after 150 cycles at 0.5C. (c, f) Schematic illustration of microstructural structure evolution for C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> and O-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span> cathodes after cycling. (g) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a> of C-Na</span><sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathodes at selected states of discharged 2.15&nbsp;V, charged 2.6&nbsp;V, discharged 2.8&nbsp;V, discharged 3.4&nbsp;V, charged 3.8&nbsp;V and 4.2&nbsp;V after 10 cycles.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0015"><h2 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045">In summary, we have successfully synthesized C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode with stable <em>P</em>2-type structure by regulating the preferred orientation of crystal plane. Its excellent cycling performance was due to the mitigation of interlaminar stress and intragranular fatigue cracks, its enlarged sodium-ion diffusion channels and structural integrity. Notably, C-Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode displays superior capacity retention of 94.8&nbsp;% after 150 cycles at 80 mAh/g. It is a simple but efficient method to rationally design stable <em>P</em>2-type structure. It introduces new design guidelines that can help to stabilize the structure of layered transition metal cathodes.</div></section><section id="s0025"><h2 id="st045" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055"><strong>Changsheng Yang:</strong> Formal analysis, Writing â€“ original draft, Writing â€“ review &amp; editing, Methodology, Validation, Investigation, Data curation. <strong>Xiang Peng:</strong> Methodology, Software, Validation, Formal analysis, Investigation, Data curation, Writing â€“ original draft. <strong>Jiale Yu:</strong> Formal analysis, Software, Data curation. <strong>Shengkai Li:</strong> Formal analysis, Software, Data curation. <strong>Haiyan Zhang:</strong> Conceptualization, Resources, Writing â€“ review &amp; editing, Project administration, Funding acquisition, Supervision.</div></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of Competing Interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ak005"><h2 id="st055" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065">This work is supported by the Regional Innovation and Development Joint Fund, National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. U20A20249), the Science and Technology Program of Guangdong Province of China (Grant No. 2022A0505030028), and the Guangzhou Emerging Industry Development Fund Project of Guangzhou Development and Reform Commissionï¼ˆFile no.2018/841ï¼‰<strong>.</strong></div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="s0035"><h2 id="st065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. 3.252-3.837 3.93 2.113.895 7.048-9.25 9.41-15.394zM14.32 24.874c4.767-1.526 14.735-2.974 15.152-1.407.824-3.157-13.72-.37-15.153 1.407zm5.28-5.043c2.31 3.237 9.816 7.498 9.788 3.82-.306 2.046-6.66-1.097-8.925-4.164-4.087-5.534-2.39-8.772-1.682-8.732.917.047 1.074 1.307.67 2.442-.173-1.406-.58-2.44-1.224-2.415-1.835.067-1.905 4.46 1.37 9.065z" fill="#f91d0a"></path></svg><span class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">H Zhu, Z Yao, Y Huang, J Zhang</div><div id="ref-id-opti5GfFOCOfq" class="title text-m">Unblocking oxygen charge compensation for stabilized highâ€voltage structure in P2â€type sodium-ion cathode</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Adv. Sci. (2022), p. 2200498, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/advs.202200498" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10.1002/advs.202200498</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85127299706&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-opti5GfFOCOfq"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Unblocking%20oxygen%20charge%20compensation%20for%20stabilized%20highvoltage%20structure%20in%20P2type%20sodium-ion%20cathode&amp;publication_year=2022&amp;author=H%20Zhu&amp;author=Z%20Yao&amp;author=Y%20Huang&amp;author=J%20Zhang" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-opti5GfFOCOfq"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (15)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2211285524010127"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Air-stable manganese-based layered oxide cathode enabled by surface modification and doping strategy for advanced sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Nano Energy</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Next-generation post-lithium batteries made from inexpensive sustainable resources have raised tremendous attention as power sources for portable electronic devices and electric vehicles [1â€“3].</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0030">P2-type layered oxide materials have attracted widespread attention as advanced cathodes for sodium-ion batteries due to their excellent rate potential and attractive cost-effectiveness. However, the unexpected dissolution of transition metal (TM) ions and the annoying Jahn-Teller effect leading to rapid capacity fading and low capacity remain obstacles to their commercial applications. To tackle these handicaps, we introduced a synergistic effect based on surface modification and doping strategies to obtain air-stable sodium carbonate (Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>) protective aluminum (Al)-doped manganese-based layered oxide cathode. The surface Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> nanolayer is created by converting residual alkali ions, which enhances the air stability of the cathode and scavenges hydrofluoric acid into the fluoride-rich cathode electrolyte interphase layer during cycling, resulting in a steady interfacial interaction. In addition, Al doping causes TMO<sub>6</sub>-octahedral shrinkage and inhibits structural distortion, thereby affecting structural evolution and phase transition. These findings provide valuable insights into improving the performance of layer oxide cathodes for next-generation low-cost batteries.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S138589472404960X"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Advancements in cathode technology, recycling strategies, and market dynamics: A comprehensive review of sodium ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Chemical Engineering Journal</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Compared to the O-Na0.67MnO2 cathode, the C- Na0.67MnO2 cathode has more stable sodium-ion diffusion channels and a lamellar structure (Fig. 3a). The potential for creating high-performance sodium-ion batteries is shown by an initial capacity of 106.8 mAh/g and capacity retention of 94.8 % after 150 cycles at 80 mA/g [47]. The low cost, non-toxic, eco-friendly, and abundant nature of Mn-based P2-layered oxide cathodes have resulted in a highly competitive market.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010">The rising demand for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) in commercial applications emphasizes the importance of meeting commercial criteria. Despite their potential, SIBs encounter challenges related to specific energy, cycling life, and specific power due to the unique characteristics of sodium ions. Design strategies, surface engineering, and structural modifications for cathode materials have been devised to improve the electrochemical performance of SIBs. In SIBs, the energy density primarily depends on the choice of cathode materials. Common cathode materials nowadays include transition metal oxides, polyanionic compounds, and Prussian blue analogs (PBAs). Enhancing these materials through targeted modifications to overcome their limitations is crucial for transitioning them from lab-scale to practical use. However, there are still some challenges to address before cathode materials can be effectively utilized for large-scale energy storage in SIBs.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Recycling spent SIBs poses significant economic and environmental challenges, particularly compared to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). Despite progress in cathode materials, thorough environmental assessments and detailed inventory data are lacking for SIBs. The early stage of their development restricts metal recycling in SIBs, underscoring the significance of end-of-life treatment. Pyrometallurgy and hydrometallurgy are commonly employed for metal recovery, with pyrometallurgy favored for SIBs due to reduced sodium evaporation risks.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0020">The marketing and commercialization trends in SIBs reflect the growing demand for renewable energy solutions. SIBs, with their potential for grid-scale energy storage, are expected to support the expansion of renewable energy infrastructure. However, overcoming technological challenges and reducing costs are key to SIB commercialization. In this regard, startups are playing a significant role in advancing SIB technologies for large-scale energy storage applications. The collaboration between companies and advancements in manufacturing facilities are driving SIB production, marking substantial progress towards commercialization. This paper aims to provide a comprehensive review of the current research and advancements in SIB technology.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979723025134"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Promoting threshold voltage of P2-Na&lt;inf&gt;0.67&lt;/inf&gt;Ni&lt;inf&gt;0.33&lt;/inf&gt;Mn&lt;inf&gt;0.67&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt; with Cu&lt;sup&gt;2+&lt;/sup&gt; cation doping toward high-stability cathode for sodium-ion battery</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Additionally, the lattice parameters â€œaâ€ and â€œcâ€ of NNCM increased because of the smaller ionic sizes of Mn4+ (ionic radius of 0.53 Ã…) and Ni2+ (0.69 Ã…) compared with Cu2+ (0.73 Ã…) [25,39]. Notably, a larger value of â€œcâ€ corresponds to a higher rate of Na+ diffusion during the charging/discharging process [41,42]. To observe structural changes at high voltages, we first charged the assembled coin cell to 4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4, 4.5, and 4.6 V at small current densities.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">P2-type Na<sub>0.67</sub>Ni<sub>0.33</sub>Mn<sub>0.67</sub>O<sub>2</sub> has attracted considerable attraction as a cathode material for sodium-ion batteries owing to its high operating voltage and theoretical specific capacity. However, when the charging voltage is higher than 4.2&nbsp;V, the Na<sub>0.67</sub>Ni<sub>0.33</sub>Mn<sub>0.67</sub>O<sub>2</sub> cathode undergoes a detrimental irreversible phase transition of P2-O2, leading to a drastic decrease in specific capacity. To address this challenge, we implemented a Cu-doping strategy (Na<sub>0.67</sub>Ni<sub>0.23</sub>Cu<sub>0.1</sub>Mn<sub>0.67</sub>O<sub>2</sub>) in this work to stabilize the structure of the transition metal layer. The stabilization strategy involved reinforcing the transition metalâ€“oxygen (TM<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O) bonds, particularly the Mn<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O bond and inhibiting interlayer slip during deep desodiation. As a result, the irreversible phase transition voltage is delayed, with the threshold voltage increasing from 4.2 to 4.4&nbsp;V. Ex-situ X-ray diffraction measurements revealed that the Na<sub>0.67</sub>Ni<sub>0.23</sub>Cu<sub>0.1</sub>Mn<sub>0.67</sub>O<sub>2</sub> cathode maintains the P2 phase within the voltage window of 2.5â€“4.3&nbsp;V, whereas the P2-Na<sub>0.67</sub>Ni<sub>0.33</sub>Mn<sub>0.67</sub>O<sub>2</sub> cathode transforms entirely into O2-type Na<sub>0.67</sub>Ni<sub>0.33</sub>Mn<sub>0.67</sub>O<sub>2</sub> when the voltage exceeds 4.3&nbsp;V. Furthermore, absolute P2-O2 phase transition of the Na<sub>0.67</sub>Ni<sub>0.23</sub>Cu<sub>0.1</sub>Mn<sub>0.67</sub>O<sub>2</sub> cathode occurred at 4.6&nbsp;V, indicating that Cu<sup>2+</sup> doping enhances the stability of the layer structure and increases the threshold voltage. The resulting Na<sub>0.67</sub>Ni<sub>0.23</sub>Cu<sub>0.1</sub>Mn<sub>0.67</sub>O<sub>2</sub> cathode exhibited superior electrochemical properties, demonstrating an initial reversible specific capacity of 89.1 mAh/g at a rate of 2C (360&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) and retaining more than 78&nbsp;% of its capacity after 500 cycles.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979723012377"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Tuning oxygen release of sodium-ion layered oxide cathode through synergistic surface coating and doping</span></span></a></h3><div>2023, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">However, anionic oxygen redox can lead to the migration of irreversible transition metal ions, resulting in sharp voltage and capacity decays during charging/discharging, which limits their practical applications [23â€“28]. To perpetuate the lifespan of Mn-based materials, constructing stable coating layers on the surface of cathode particles is an effective approach [9,29â€“34]. Ji et al. modified an Al2O3 nanolayer with a thickness of 3 nm on the surface of a P2-Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2 cathode material.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-3-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-3" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010">Layered transition metal oxides have the greatest potential for commercial application as cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries. However, transition metal oxides inevitably undergo an irreversible oxygen loss process during cycling, which leads to structural changes in the material and ultimately to severe capacity degradation. In this work, using density function theory (DFT) calculations, the Ni-O bond is revealed to be the weakest of the Mâˆ’O bonds, which may lead to structural failure. Herein, the synergistic surface CeO<sub>2</sub> modification and the trace doping of Ce elements stimulate oxygen redox and improve its reversibility, thus improving the structural stability and electrochemical performance of the material. Theoretical calculations prove that Na<sub>0.67</sub>Mn<sub>0.7</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Co<sub>0.1</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (MNC) obtains electrons from CeO<sub>2</sub>, avoiding destruction of the Ni-O bond by over-energy released during the charging process and inhibiting oxygen loss. The capacity retention was 77.37% for 200 cycles at 500&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, compared to 33.84% for the unmodified Na<sub>0.67</sub>Mn<sub>0.7</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Co<sub>0.1</sub>O<sub>2</sub>. Overall, the present work demonstrates that the synergistic effect of surface coating and doping is an effective strategy for realizing tuning oxygen release and high electrochemical performance.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1039/d4cs00415a" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Sodium layered oxide cathodes: properties, practicality and prospects</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2024, Chemical Society Reviews</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1039/d3cs00929g" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Routes to high-performance layered oxide cathodes for sodium-ion batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();
